title: Temporal Trends in Traffic Stops
text:
AQ1: How does the frequency of traffic stops vary throughout the day, and are there consistent “peak” or “low” hours in 2005 versus 2015?


Exploring General Hourly Patterns in Traffic Stops with Yearly Comparison and Time-Period Summaries






View 1



AQ2: Are specific combinations of temporal factors (ex: Friday nights, winter mornings) associated with particular types of violations?



Temporal Patterns of Police Stops by Reason, Day of the Week, Season, and Hour






View 2



AQ3: Are certain types of traffic stop outcomes common at specific times of day?



Patterns in Traffic Stop Outcomes by Time of Day






View 3

title: Data
text:
This dataset is a record of all traffic stops in the city of Charlotte, North Carolina, United States in 2005 and 2015. Charlotte is the capitol and largest city in North Carolina, and is a major urban population center in the United States. The dataset records the date, time, and location of the traffic stop; the age, sex, and ethnicity of the driver; the reason for the traffic stop, including suspicion of drugs, weapons, or illegal activity; whether the car was searched and if anything was found; and whether a citation or warning was issued, or an arrest was made. The raw data comes as separate files for each city center, which must be combined into a cohesive dataset. The raw data is much too large for Altair to handle with nearly 4 million observations between the years of 2000 and 2015, so we have taken a random sample of 400,000 observations between 2010 and 2015 for our analysis.



The dataset comes from the Stanford Open Policing Project (SOPP), available here. The project was created to improve transparency and enable research on racial disparities in police traffic stops across the United States.
To build this dataset, the SOPP team filed hundreds of public records requests to state and local law enforcement agencies under Freedom of Information laws. Millions of individual traffic stop records were gathered and standardized across jurisdictions to ensure consistent variable names. The data was collected to analyze, document, and share patterns of policing behavior, so researchers, journalists, and policymakers could be informed on how disparities occur.

title: Data
text:
This dataset is a record of all traffic stops in the city of Charlotte, North Carolina, United States in 2005 and 2015. Charlotte is the capitol and largest city in North Carolina, and is a major urban population center in the United States. The dataset records the date, time, and location of the traffic stop; the age, sex, and ethnicity of the driver; the reason for the traffic stop, including suspicion of drugs, weapons, or illegal activity; whether the car was searched and if anything was found; and whether a citation or warning was issued, or an arrest was made. The raw data comes as separate files for each city center, which must be combined into a cohesive dataset. The raw data is much too large for Altair to handle with nearly 4 million observations between the years of 2000 and 2015, so we have taken a random sample of 400,000 observations between 2010 and 2015 for our analysis.



The dataset comes from the Stanford Open Policing Project (SOPP), available here. The project was created to improve transparency and enable research on racial disparities in police traffic stops across the United States.
To build this dataset, the SOPP team filed hundreds of public records requests to state and local law enforcement agencies under Freedom of Information laws. Millions of individual traffic stop records were gathered and standardized across jurisdictions to ensure consistent variable names. The data was collected to analyze, document, and share patterns of policing behavior, so researchers, journalists, and policymakers could be informed on how disparities occur.

boolean
Whether the stopped driver was issued a warning
2 unique values

ordinal
The final outcome of the traffic stop, i.e. whether the driver was warned, issued a citation, arrested, or had no consequenc
4 unique values

boolean
Whether contrabound was found in the car
2 unique values

Whether illegal drugs were found in the car
2 unique values

boolean
Whether illegal weapons were found in the car
2 unique values

boolean
Whether the driver was frisked

boolean
Whether a search of the driver or car was performed
2 unique values

Whether a search of the driver was conducted
2 unique values

boolean
Whether a search of the vehicle was conducted
2 unique values

nominal
The official basis for the search, cleaned
3 unique values


reason_for_frisk
string
The official basis for the frisk, as a combination of string choices
59 unique values


reason_for_search
string
The official basis for the search, as a combination of string choices
28 unique values


reason_for_stop
string
The official basis for the stop, as a single string choice
10 unique values


raw_Ethnicity
nominal
The uncleaned ethnicity of the driver (whether or not the driver is hispanic)
2 unique values

title: Racial Disparities in Traffic Stops
text:
AQ1: How do police stop outcomes differ across racial groups and age ranges, and what patterns emerge in the distribution of ages and outcomes within each race?


Stop Outcome Patterns Across Various Racial Groups and Ages






View 1



AQ2: How do different types of police actions relate to each search type (person search, vehicle search, both, or neither), and how do these patterns differ across race groups and age distributions?



Action and Search Type Relationships Across Demographics






View 2



AQ3: How do age distributions differ between individuals who were arrested and those who were not, and how do contraband findings among these groups change over time when examining specific subsets of individuals?



Age, Arrest Outcomes, and Contraband Patterns Over Time






View 3

title: DSCI 320 Project
text:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

# Load raw CSV
raw = pd.read_csv("brianna_dec2.csv")

# Clean race
clean = raw.copy()

clean["subject_race"] = (
    clean["subject_race"]
    .astype(str)
    .str.lower()
    .str.strip()
)

clean = clean[~clean["subject_race"].isin(["other", "unknown", "none", "", None])]
clean = clean[clean["subject_race"].notna()]

# Clean Action Description
clean["raw_action_description"] = (
    clean["raw_action_description"]
    .fillna("unknown")
    .astype(str)
    .str.strip()
    .str.title()
)

clean = clean[clean["raw_action_description"] != "Unknown"]
clean = clean[clean["raw_action_description"] != ""]


# Clean age and ensure data type is correct
clean = clean.dropna(subset=["subject_age"])
clean["subject_age"] = pd.to_numeric(clean["subject_age"], errors="coerce")
clean = clean.dropna(subset=["subject_age"])

# Convert datetime 
clean["datetime"] = pd.to_datetime(clean["datetime"], errors="coerce")
clean = clean.dropna(subset=["datetime"])

clean["year"] = clean["datetime"].dt.year.astype(int)

# Clean Search flags + create `search_intrusiveness`
clean["search_person"] = clean["search_person"].fillna(0).astype(int)
clean["search_vehicle"] = clean["search_vehicle"].fillna(0).astype(int)

def classify_intrusiveness(row):
    p = row["search_person"]
    v = row["search_vehicle"]
    
    if p == 1 and v == 1:
        return "Both"
    elif p == 1 and v == 0:
        return "Person Only"
    elif p == 0 and v == 1:
        return "Vehicle Only"
    else:
        return "Neither"

clean["search_intrusiveness"] = clean.apply(classify_intrusiveness, axis=1)

# Clean Search Basis
clean = clean.dropna(subset=["search_basis"])
clean["search_basis"] = clean["search_basis"].astype(str).str.strip()

# Clean labels for views (arrest and race label)
clean["arrest_made"] = clean["arrest_made"].astype(int)

clean["arrest_status_label"] = clean["arrest_made"].map({
    0: "Not Arrested",
    1: "Arrested"
})

clean["race_label"] = clean["subject_race"].map({
    "asian/pacific islander": "Asian / Pacific Islander",
    "black": "Black",
    "hispanic": "Hispanic",
    "white": "White"
})

clean = clean.dropna(subset=["race_label", "arrest_status_label"])

clean = clean.copy()
clean.to_csv("cleaned_master_dataset.csv", index=False)





search_intrusiveness
Both            9617
Person Only     1149
Vehicle Only     773
Neither           21
Name: count, dtype: int64

title: Patterns of Driver Sex and Age in Traffic Stops
text:
AQ1: How does the probability of a driver being stopped change with driver age and driver sex?


Patterns in Stop Probability by Driver Age and Driver Sex






View 1



AQ2: How does the outcome of the traffic stop vary between drivers of different ages and sexes, and which driver age range and sex are most associated with a poor traffic stop outcome (i.e. arrest)?



Patterns of Stop Outcome Among Male and Female Drivers






View 2



AQ3: How do the relationships between driver age, driver sex, and traffic stop likelihood change between 2005 and 2015?



Changes in Stop Likelihood Between 2005 and 2015






View 3

title: Project Team Bear
text:
Welcome to the Project Team Bear website. This site hosts our data project deliverables, visualizations, and short write-ups produced by each team member.


This project is designed for students, researchers, policymakers, and community members who are interested in understanding how race and ethnicity shape experiences with police traffic stops. By presenting clear, interactive visualizations, our goal is to make the data accessible to non-technical audiences while still providing enough depth to support evidence-based discussions about equity, bias, and policing practices in the United States.


Our analysis uses traffic stop data from the Stanford Open Policing Project (SOPP), available here. It is a large-scale initiative that compiles millions of stop records obtained through public records requests to law enforcement agencies nationwide. The SOPP dataset provides standardized variables such as driver demographics, stop reason, search details, contraband findings, and stop outcomes (e.g., warnings, citations, arrests).
For this project, we focus on the city of Charlotte, North Carolina for the years 2005 and 2015 . As the full dataset is too large for Altair’s rendering limits (nearly 4 million observations from 2000–2015), our group worked with either curated subsets or random samples appropriate for each exploratory analysis. The specific fields we used vary across team members but include age, race, action taken, search intrusiveness, contraband type, and stop outcomes.
A quick navigation to each team member’s page:

Temporal Race and Ethnicity Sex and Age Outcomes



Anyone interested in how race and ethnicity shape experiences with traffic stops including students, researchers, and policymakers. This project helps reveal where differences in treatment appear, such as during searches or arrests. Ultimately, by using data and presenting our insights clearly, we aim to encourage discussions about equity, accountability, and bias in law enforcement practices.








Edward Sobczak: I’m majoring in Microbiology & Immunology and minoring in Data Science, and I enjoy crocheting!
Alex Haddon: I study Economics and Data Science and I love to ski ⛷️
Brianna Chau: I am a third year Economics student, with a minor in Data Science. I am interested in strength training, cardio, and watching my macros!
Roxanna Ng: I am majoring in Political Science and minoring in Data Science, and I enjoy exploring good restaurants!

title: Patterns in Traffic Stop Outcomes
text:
AQ1: What are the patterns between a reason for a traffic stop and its outcome over different months and years, and how might this change depending on whether there was a search conducted?


Traffic Stop Outcomes by Reason for Stop and Whether a Search was Conducted, Over Months and Years
This view is too large to be hosted with GitHub. Please render locally.

AQ2: What are the patterns between the outcome of a stop and the reason for a stop, across different ages?



Subject Ages by Reason for a Traffic Stop and Outcome






View 2



AQ3: Given the intersection between specific instances of a reason for stop and the subject’s sex, what are the patterns between whether action was taken over different months, and how might this vary depending on whether a search or frisk was conducted?



Traffic Stop Outcome by Sex, Reason for Stop, and Whether A Frisk and/or Search Was Conducted






View 3
